Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

The provided CT scan image shows significant periosteal thickening and sclerosis within the diaphysis of the bone, accompanied by central lucency. These radiological features are characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone, leading to extensive periosteal reaction, sclerosis, and central areas of bone destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Typically presents with a large soft tissue mass and periosteal reaction. The symmetrical soft tissue in the image makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Usually arises in the metaphysis, with characteristic sunburst periosteal reaction and periosteal lifting, not observed in this diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option D. Fracture: Would present with a distinct fracture line, which is not visible in the image provided. The periosteal reaction and sclerosis are also not typical for a simple fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: Whole- body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT limbs

 

Explanation:

 

CT Limbs is not included in the whole-body CT of a trauma patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Head: Non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head to check for any intracranial hemorrhages or fractures.

 

Option B. CT Cervical Spine: NCCT of the cervical spine to assess for any fractures or dislocations that may compromise the spinal cord.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT of the torso, including the abdomen and pelvis, to evaluate for internal injuries such as organ lacerations, bleeding, or other trauma-related abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole-body CT or trauma CT includes:

 

  1. NCCT head
  2. NCCT C-spine
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of torso

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

 

Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect / spinal dysraphism which can occur to varying degrees of severity. It is often considered the most common congenital CNS malformation.

 

Banana sign - Refers to the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis, which appears elongated and curved, resembling the shape of a banana.

 

Lemon sign - In prenatal ultrasound, when spina bifida is present, the base of the skull can appear abnormal and shaped like a lemon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where abdominal contents protrude into the umbilical cord. This condition is associated with various ultrasound findings, but not specifically with the Banana sign.

 

Option C. Down’s syndrome: Characterized by the presence of an extra chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), Down’s syndrome has associated ultrasound markers like increased nuchal translucency and absent nasal bone, but not the Banana sign.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: A genetic condition affecting males, characterized by an extra X chromosome (XXY). This condition is typically identified through genetic testing and is not associated with the Banana sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: A young male is complaining of pain, and the image shows a lesion in the diaphysis. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • The X-ray shows a lesion in the diaphysis of the bone, consistent with an osteoid osteoma. This is characterized by a small, benign, and painful tumor usually found in the cortex of long bones, such as the femur or tibia.
  • Osteoid osteomas are typically less than 2 cm in size and can cause significant pain, often worse at night, which is relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone tumor that usually arises near the growth plate of a long bone. These tumors manifest as a cartilage-capped bony projection on the surface of the bone and do not typically present as a central diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option B. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT): This tumor often occurs near the end of the bone and extends to the joint. It usually affects adults between 20 and 40 years old and may be more aggressive than an osteoid osteoma.

 

Option C. Unicameral Bone Cyst (Simple Bone Cyst): This is a fluid-filled bone cavity typically found in the metaphysis of long bones in children and young adults. It generally does not cause significant pain unless there is a pathological fracture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TLD badge

 

Explanation:

 

Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

 

 

  • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • Personnel dosimeter.
  • Thermoluminescent
  • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • Made up of CaSO4: Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.

 

Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.

 

Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

 

The given X-ray shows the fracture of the 4th, 5th, 6th rib.

 

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.
